comments.commentBody: Well I disagree....   he could have been trying to unarm him....   it doesn't mean that he didn't have his own gun.  But if he HAD a gun, I'm pretty sure he would have started shooting back at some point.

So what's his excuse for shooting him as he fled...Mike Brown wasnt shot and killed at close range...cant see how it's possible for a cop with a gun in his hand to fear for his life by an unarmed man 20-30 feet from him...I think this cop flipped out...and just decided to put this kid down for good, out of anger or some other emotion...it's either that, or a terribly awful, I'd say negligent at best, case of bad judgement on Wilson's part. I think its one or the other.
This is the first I had heard it was an SUV!  That makes a difference.   There is just too much about this that is NOT clear and I think there needs to be a trial.  A PUBLIC trial.

Although we will never KNOW, what you say sounds like what I believe happened, beginning to end.  Brown was disrespectful, he was a petty criminal, he should have just done what he was told....   yes....  however, he didn't deserve to die for it and I do believe Wilson was either scared or angry and in either case, was not thinking rationally as he continued to shoot after the real threat was over.  And that is NOT OK for an armed, trained officer.

A political crisis manager as Ebola Czar is surprising until you realize that this crisis will be 1. Political, 2. Political, and 3. About lack of Ebola preparedness. The rational strategy would be to analyze the errors and omissions and fix them without any defensiveness or excuses. When everything is politicized admitting to error results in public humiliation and trashing of careers. Errors are defended or hidden. Adopting outside advice looks like an admission of error. Extreme reactions look good because they seem like acts of leadership. Depressing.

"She also brought in efficiency experts who were anathema to scientists"

I too have been perplexed by the CDC's incompetence regarding Ebola, but the above observation gives sense to the hubris shown by CDC personnel.

Managers manage through metrics which give them control, & tend to lead to a "silo" mentality. Those who flourish in such an environment learn how to better manage targets rather than actual problems.

But visionaries, or even those who would apply common sense to problems, tend to have a harder time. It is incomprehensible that groups like Médecins sans Frontières were not consulted in establishing protocols.

Appointing an Ebola czar who is an administrator, without any public health expertise, does not inspire confidence in the possibility of a rationale policy.

Part of what got cut from the public health budgets was training for handling emergencies. It is like the agency has a fire extinguisher, but the GOP refuses to give the agency money to test it. The agency is afraid the extinguisher is getting old and needs to be replaced; the GOP refuses that request, too. Then there is a fire. The fire extinguisher doesn't work. Ebola was an unknown disease prior to 1976 when it appeared for the first time in Sudan.

Yes, the CDC might be able to get little right, and it cannot be excused by arguing sequestration --Ebola is an old foe, and protocols for it were developed years, decades, before sequestration.

Yet when enemy number 1 of government is a major political party dead set in destroying confidence, the economy, and willing to spew falsehood in order to gain political points, what can the CDC do?

Had the CDC told us that in truth not much is known about the virus infection vectors, that it could not assess the risk of contagion in a standard hospital, etc., we can all be but sure that the GOP would be assailing the CDC with the same vindictiveness and fury as they are doing today.

As a matter of fact, this "defensive political medicine" carried out by the CDC is still what is hobbling the US and the world's response to Ebola. The CDC, if it had no fear of political blow back, would state the obvious for us to hear: that in the coming months Ebola's risk to the average American is near zero, but that, if the situation in West Africa remains as it is, once hundreds of thousands of cases arise, then the medium to long term prospect for a calamity of serious consequences in America, with Americans dying, is in the cards.

There is no evidence that Michael Brown had just committed a felony and in Missouri, there is no such crime as a "strong-arm robbery" - that is a layman's term. If Brown was concerned about being picked up by the police for a robbery he had just committed, he certainly did not act like it. He was just casually ambling down the middle of a street near his home, although he had plenty of time to be home or somewhere else to hide. (The merchant he is said to have robbed did not call the police.) Darren Wilson's police chief said Wilson knew nothing of the so-called robbery (the chief later amended that statement to claim he learned of it after first accosting Brown, but the timeframe of the incident makes that highly unlikely). Yes, I am downplaying the incident at the market for the reasons I've noted as well as because the stills and the videotape do not show either the full incident nor show clearly what happened. I certainly want to hear more, but I cannot for the life of me understand why you are so certain that deadly force was necessary. I am also downplaying the incident because it is irrelevant to Wilson's shooting of an unarmed young man who was first in retreat, then surrender. The market video was shown to stir up community animosity and it appears to have worked. If the police had anything to commend the officer's action, I'm sure they would have shown that rather than attempt to smear the victim.

Good point. No one seems to have said he was going after the officer. Most seem to indicate the boy had been shot and was staggering in the officers direction, possibly surrendering, when the coup de grace was administered. And the distance of the shooting was estimated t be 20-25 ft. That's the same as Brown being on the roof of a two story building and Wilson being on the ground.

The only thing that proves is that Wilson was a marksman.

It's obvious no charges are warranted because the legal bar to prove a charge like murder or manslaughter just became too high. The FBI investigation -- not the local police -- shows two shots fired in the car and Brown's blood on the gun. That essentially proves Brown went for the gun. With at least some witnesses claiming Brown, once outside the car, ignored an order to stop and came toward the officer, it would be reasonable for the officer to assume Brown would go for the gun again. Also, because Brown already went for the gun once, it would be reasonable for the officer to fear for his life. Remember that court cases are not won or lost based on what is morally right and wrong. They are won or lost based on what can be proven beyond a reasonably doubt.

@A Goldstein:

Great comment (seriously). And yes, we do need to have an even-mannered discussion, a dialogue. Sadly, our nation is so divided, I doubt it'll happen.

It'll be lots of one-sided lectures.

"Steps can hopefully then be taken to lessen the possibility of similar events happening again and again."
On whose side? The guy who charged the cop and assaulted him or the policeman who was fighting for his life? Which side would you like to lessen the possibility of a re-occurrence? Remember, this is not a simple case of a 17 year old with skittles in his pocket.

The one fact that is uncontested is that Brown reached into the driver's side of the police car and struggled with the officer. Forensic evidence indicates that the officer suffered physical injury and that there was a struggle over the officer's pistol that resulted in two shots being fired, one of which apparently struck Brown.

With those facts in mind, what would a dialogue that attempts to "discuss and understand the actions and the motives of both the shooter and the victim" entail? This is not a movie. The motivations of each party, while of interest to dramatists and writers, is not really relevant since they cannot be reliably established. The best that can be done here is to get a reasonable understanding of the physical actions that were taken by both men. Besides, whatever motivated Brown can never be determined, whereas, any motivational claims by the officer would be seen as self-serving and discounted.

The only dialogue that I can see from this case involves pointing out that whoever you are, regardless of your sex, color, race, or creed, never reach into a police car and struggle with the officer. It will always end badly.

Most of the comments about this article are parsing details, pointing out inconsistencies or citing additional putative details of the events that led to Mr. Wilson shooting Mr. Brown to death. Most commenters are trying to identify a bright line that points to Mr. Wilson's or Mr. Brown's guilt or innocence. But regardless of the verdict, we desperately need a dialog to discuss and understand the actions and the motives of both the shooter and the victim. Steps can hopefully then be taken to lessen the possibility of similar events happening again and again. That is the outcome we should be trying to achieve.
